speaker.whotheyare: Prosanta Chakrabarty studies fish to help explain the evolution of human beings and our planet.
speaker.whylisten:
Dr. Prosanta Chakrabarty is a full professor and the curator of fishes at the Museum of Natural Science and Department of Biological Sciences at Louisiana State University. He is also a research associate at the American Museum of Natural History, Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History and the Canadian Museum of Nature.

Chakrabarty is a systematist and an ichthyologist studying the evolution and biogeography of fishes. His work has taken him to more than 35 countries around the world (including Japan, Australia, Brazil, Taiwan, Madagascar, Panama, Kuwait and the Galapagos). He has published more than 100 scientific papers and four books, including Explaining Life Through Evolution. He is a former program director at the National Science Foundation, an elected fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, a Fulbright Distinguished Chair and a TED Senior Fellow. He is the president-elect of the American Society of Ichthyologists and Herpetologists and has described more than 15 species of fishes new to science, including cavefishes and deep-sea fishes. He grew up in New York City, his undergraduate degree is from McGill University in Montreal (the city where he was born) and his PhD is from the University of Michigan.
